title: Labour MP suspended over sexual harassment allegation
text:
Mr Hepburn has been a Labour Party MP since 1997 (Picture: Chris McAndrew/UK Parliament)

Labour MP Stephen Hepburn has been suspended from the party after a complaint regarding sexual harassment.

The allegation dates back to 2005, where it is alleged that the MP for Jarrow, Gateshead, cornered a party member in her 20s and tried to ‘accompany her home in a taxi’.

A complaint about the MPs conduct was first made two years ago, but was dropped, HuffPost UK reported.

However, it has been reopened after another MP came forward, saying they had witnessed the incident take place.

The witness alleges that Mr Hepburn allowed the woman ‘little or no freedom of movement’ and described him as acting ‘predatory’.

Now that the case has been reopened, it is understood to have been referred to the National Constitutional Committee.

The alleged incident involving the MP is said to have taken place in 2005 (Picture: UK Parliament)

The Labour Party says it takes all complaints of sexual harassment extremely seriously

The Labour Party said it takes all complaints of sexual harassment ‘extremely seriously’.

Mr Hepburn has been an MP since 1997.

The panel which took the decision, was advised by an independent barrister, following a report carried out by an independent investigator, and was anonymised so the panel did not know who the individual was.

A Labour Party spokeswoman said: ‘The Labour Party takes all complaints of sexual harassment extremely seriously, which are fully investigated and any appropriate disciplinary action taken in line with the Party’s rules and procedures.

‘We are determined to challenge and overturn sexual harassment and misogyny within politics and across society as a whole. We cannot comment on individual complaints.’

Mr Hepburn says he ‘welcomes the investigation so that the matter can be put to rest’.
